verse_commentaries.commentary: The verse uses two parallel question structures with מִי, creating liturgical tension. The pairing of 'tent' (אֹהֶל) and 'holy mountain' (הַר קׇדְשֶׁךָ) is curious - tent suggests temporality/wilderness period while mountain suggests permanence/Zion. The verbs יָגוּר (sojourn) vs יִשְׁכֹּן (dwell) create semantic gradation from temporary to permanent residence.

lexical_insights.notes: Sojourn/dwell as alien - technical term for resident alien status, contrasts with permanent dwelling
Permanent dwelling - stronger settlement term than gar, also used of divine presence
Tent imagery - archaic worship language recalling tabernacle, surprisingly paired with temple mountain
Holy mountain - Zion temple language, creates tension with tent vocabulary

figurative_analysis: Tent and mountain as metaphors for divine presence - blending temporal/eternal imagery
Spatial language (in/on) as metaphor for relationship with God
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Directly establishes the spatial-to-ethical transformation thesis - opening with physical location questions that will be answered with ethical requirements

verse_commentaries.commentary: The verse presents a triadic structure moving from external behavior (הוֹלֵךְ) to active deed (וּפֹעֵל) to internal disposition (וְדֹבֵר...בִּלְבָבֽוֹ). The phrase 'speaks truth in his heart' is striking - internalized truthfulness rather than just external speech. The participles create ongoing, habitual action rather than one-time acts.

lexical_insights.notes: Walks blamelessly - tamim is crucial ethical-cultic term (wholeness, completeness, integrity), used of Noah and sacrificial animals
Does/works righteousness - po'el suggests active manufacturing/crafting of justice
Speaks truth in heart - unusual phrase suggesting internalized truthfulness, not just truthful speech

figurative_analysis: 'Walking' as metaphor for total lifestyle/conduct - wisdom literature commonplace
'Heart' as seat of thought/will, not just emotion - cognitive center
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes the holistic ethical profile - external walk, active work, internal disposition - supporting thesis of comprehensive ethical requirement, not just ritual

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift to negative formulations (לֹא repeated three times) defining righteousness by exclusion. The phrase לֹא־רָגַל עַל־לְשֹׁנוֹ is puzzling - 'not slandered/walked on his tongue' creates unusual body-part imagery. Three social spheres mentioned: tongue (speech), רֵעֵהוּ (fellow), קְרֹבוֹ (close one/neighbor) - expanding circles of relationship.

lexical_insights.notes: Slandered with/on his tongue - ragal can mean spy out, slander; unusual construction with 'on tongue' - does it mean walking/going about with slander?
His fellow/neighbor - general term for associate, companion
His close one/kinsman - from root meaning 'near,' suggests closer relationship than re'a, possibly family
Reproach/disgrace - bearing or lifting up reproach, weightier than mere gossip
Lift up/bear/carry - used with cherpa suggests spreading or accepting disgraceful reports

figurative_analysis: Tongue as instrument/location of slander - body part metonymy
'Lifting up reproach' - spatial metaphor for spreading disgrace
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Negative definition by exclusion - supports thesis that righteousness involves discipline and boundary-setting in social relationships, not just positive actions

verse_commentaries.commentary: Sharp antithetic parallelism: despising the contemptible vs honoring God-fearers. The phrase נִבְזֶה בְּעֵינָיו נִמְאָס is striking - doubled terms (despised/rejected) for single subject. The second colon introduces יִרְאֵי יְהֹוָה (fearers of LORD) as social reference group. Final clause נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע וְלֹא יָמִֽר is powerful - oath-keeping even to one's hurt.

lexical_insights.notes: Despised in his eyes - active rejection/contempt, uses evaluative 'in eyes' idiom
Rejected/despised one - intensifies bazah, strong rejection term used of God rejecting Saul
Fearers of LORD - technical term for faithful covenant community, key identity marker
Honors/gives weight to - from kaved (heavy), suggests active honoring beyond mere respect
Swears to harm/hurt - taking oath even when disadvantageous to self
Change/exchange - oath-changing, breaking commitment for advantage

figurative_analysis: 'In his eyes' - visual/evaluative metaphor for judgment
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Introduces social values/allegiances as ethical criterion - not just personal behavior but community alignment and costly integrity. Supports thesis of comprehensive ethical profile including social positioning.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: niv-**ZEH**  bə-**ʿĒY**-nāy-w nim-**'ĀS** wə-'eth-yir-**'ĒY** yə-hō-**WĀH** yə-kha-**BĒDH** nish-**BAʿ** lə-hā-**RAʿ** wə-**LŌ'** yā-**MIR**

verse_commentaries.commentary: Two economic prohibitions: lending at interest (נֶשֶׁךְ) and taking bribes against innocent. The term נֶשֶׁךְ (bite/interest) is vivid predatory imagery. Concluding promise: עֹשֵׂה־אֵלֶּה לֹא יִמּוֹט לְעוֹלָֽם - 'doing these things, never be shaken forever' - powerful stability promise creating inclusio with dwelling question of v.1.

lexical_insights.notes: Interest/usury - from 'bite,' vivid metaphor for exploitative lending, prohibited in Torah
Bribe - gift given to pervert justice, paired with 'against innocent'
Innocent/clean one - legal term for one not guilty, undeserving of judgment
Not be shaken/moved - stability imagery, opposite of tottering/falling, used of righteous and Zion
Forever - eternal/age-long duration, strongest temporal language
Doing these things - summarizing participle gathering all previous requirements

figurative_analysis: Neshech (bite) - predatory animal imagery for exploitative lending
Lo yimmot (not shaken) - stability/foundation metaphor, contrasts with tottering/falling
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Completes the spatial-to-ethical-to-ontological transformation: physical location question (v.1) → ethical requirements (vv.2-5a) → existential stability promise (v.5b). Economic justice as climactic test supports thesis of comprehensive ethical holiness replacing ritual access.

thematic_threads: Architectural structure: Question (v.1) → Answer in positive terms (v.2) → Answer in negative terms (vv.3-5a) → Promise (v.5b)
Progression from personal/internal (v.2: heart) to social/relational (v.3: neighbor/kinsman) to communal/economic (vv.4-5: community values, financial ethics)
Anaphoric לֹא pattern intensifying through vv.3-5, creating rhythmic negation that defines by exclusion
Inclusio between dwelling/sojourning (v.1) and never being shaken (v.5b) - spatial metaphor transformed to ontological stability
Participle dominance throughout creating timeless, habitual quality - not one-time acts but lifestyle portrait
Movement from external → internal → external in v.2-3 (walk → heart → tongue → action)
Pairing of archaic (tent) and contemporary (mountain) worship language in v.1 - theological bridge between traditions
Economic ethics climax - interest and bribery as final tests places social justice at center, not ritual purity
interesting_questions: Why does the psalm pair archaic 'tent' language with permanent 'holy mountain' imagery in v.1 - is this deliberate merging of tabernacle and temple traditions?
What exactly does 'speaks truth in his heart' (דֹבֵר אֱמֶת בִּלְבָבוֹ) mean - internal self-honesty, truthful thinking, or something else? How does this differ from speaking truth to others?
What is the semantic relationship between רֵעֵהוּ (fellow) and קְרֹבוֹ (close one) in v.3 - expanding circles of responsibility, synonymous parallelism, or specific social categories?
Why is the contemptible person described with doubled language (נִבְזֶה...נִמְאָס) while God-fearers get single term (יִרְאֵי יְהֹוָה) - rhetorical emphasis or semantic distinction?
Does נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע mean taking an oath that turns out costly, or deliberately making a costly commitment? What's the nature of this 'swearing to hurt'?
Why does the psalm climax with economic sins (interest-taking, bribery) rather than cultic/ritual offenses - what does this prioritization reveal about the psalm's theology?
How does the stability promise (לֹא יִמּוֹט לְעוֹלָֽם) answer the dwelling question (מִי־יָגוּר...מִי־יִשְׁכֹּן) - are these metaphorically equivalent or distinct concepts?
What is the significance of the LXX translating 'swears to his hurt' as 'swears to his neighbor' - which reading is original and what interpretive implications?
Why are participles used throughout for ethical description - does habitual/ongoing aspect have theological significance vs. perfect tense completion?
What's the function of the unusual phrase רָגַל עַל־לְשֹׁנוֹ - does ragal mean 'spy/slander' or literally 'walk/go about' and how does this work with 'on tongue'?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Detailed study of tamim (wholeness/blamelessness), ragal construction, neshech (interest/bite), yimmot (shaken), yir'ei YHWH (God-fearers) as technical terms
CONCORDANCE: Track tent/mountain pairing across Psalter, participial ethical descriptions, lo yimmot stability promises, gar/shakan verb pairs
SYNTAX: Analyze participle usage for habitual aspect, negative constructions with lo, oath-taking syntax (nishba + l-)
FIGURATIVE: Economic metaphors (bite/interest), spatial metaphors (dwelling/shaking), body-part imagery (tongue, eyes, heart)
COMMENTARY: Focus on v.2 'truth in heart' puzzle, v.3 ragal tongue construction, v.4 LXX variance on oath, v.5 interest prohibition context and stability promise interpretation
